BIOGRAPHY

I graduated from the California State University, Fullerton (CSUF) in 2017, where my solid state chemistry research was on unconventional oxide perovskites. I am currently a graduate student in the Department of Chemistry at Princeton University. My research focuses on the synthesis and magnetic properties of hexagonal perovskites. I have discovered several new face-sharing hexagonal perovskites, several of which potentially host a quantum spin liquid state. My goal is to discover interesting properties in both known and new semiconducting perovskite compounds for better material applications.

California State University, Fullerton (CSUF)

Undergraduate researcher

My solid state chemistry research was on unconventional oxide perovskites. The key point to understand the relationship between structures and properties is to accurately determine the crystal structures of the materials. My work was to synthesize and probe the structure-property relations on perovskites by X-ray and neutron diffractions and the Physical Property Measurement System. My undergraduate advisor and I developed the criteria for forming non-cooperative octahedral tilted (NCOT) perovskites, where the materials break the conventional corner-sharing octahedral fashion.

Dojo Academy

Chemistry and SAT Math tutor

I have been teaching high school/college Math, Physics and Chemistry classes. At Dojo Academy, I designed and wrote the SAT Math materials and practice tests.

GWC, CSU Fullerton and Princeton University

Teaching Assistant

I helped teach organic chemistry class in small groups at GWC. Moreover, I was tutoring for an advanced inorganic chemistry course at CSUF. Recently, I have been teaching a material chemistry laboratory class at Princeton University in Fall 2019.
